authors: Special To The New York Times
title: KILLINGS SOAR IN 'WILD SOUTH' OF THE PHILIPPINES
title_page: KILLINGS SOAR IN 'WILD SOUTH' OF THE PHILIPPINES - The New York Times
maintext:
The southern island of Mindanao has long had a reputation as ''the Wild South'' of the Philippines.
It has been where rootless and adventurous Filipinos have come to seek their fortune in land, trading, gold-panning, and various other pursuits, legal and otherwise. Pistols and carbines have traditionally played a role in settling disputes in such Mindanao cities as Davao and Zamboanga.
But the situation has worsened. About 800 people were slain in and around Davao last year, nearly twice the number as the year before. Over last weekend, 13 people, including a gambling lord, a peanut vendor and two paramilitary soldiers, were killed in a 24-hour period in Davao.
The Government blames most of the killings on the Communists, and Communist assassination squads do roam this big port city.
The squads of the Communist guerrillas, the New Peoples Army, are undoubtedly behind many of the killings.
